all_summaries: The paper introduces Noisy Counterfactual Matching (NCM), a method that uses invariant data pairs to improve robustness to spurious correlations by adding a constraint to empirical risk minimization (ERM). NCM is theoretically proven to be robust to spurious correlations, and empirically validated on synthetic and real-world datasets, showing improved performance compared to ERM and other baselines. The method leverages counterfactual pairs from training data, which are invariant under the optimally robust classifier, to enforce orthogonality with spurious features, enhancing generalization across domains.

This paper presents a novel method called Noisy Counterfactual Matching (NCM) that enhances model robustness to spurious correlations by leveraging invariant data pairs derived from training domains. The method introduces a constraint to empirical risk minimization (ERM) ensuring predictions on invariant pairs match, thereby forcing the model to be orthogonal to spurious features. Theoretical analysis shows that NCM can provably robust to spurious correlations even with noisy counterfactuals, requiring only a small number of invariant pairs for robustness. Empirical evaluations on synthetic and real-world datasets demonstrate NCM's effectiveness in improving robustness compared to existing methods.
